title-group.article-title: In silico genomics analysis of weed Lantana camara and its proposed application in synthesis of polyhydroxybutyrate

abstract.p: Poly (3-hydroxyalkanoates) (PHAs) are a class of microbially produced polyesters that have potential applications as conventional plastics, specifically thermoplastic elastomers The most common PHA is poly-β-hydroxybutyrate (PHB), and this polymer can accumulate up to 90% of the cellular dry weight of some bacteria. We report using Lantana camara, a weed for the production of PHB to provide a cheap and abundant source of this polymer. Maturase K gene (matK) of chloroplast is highly conserved in plant, which is involved in intron splicing. Based on a computational gene sequence analysis, we propose that the L. Camara, a common weed, can be an inexpensive and abundant source for biological production of PHB. Our simulations focus on the maturase K (matK) gene – length of 1331 base pairs (bp) – of the choloroplasts, which affects the intron splicing. Our computational approach considers a reconstructed chloroplast genome of L. Camara, the trnL–trnF intergenic spacer (IGS), and trnH–psbA IGS in the chloroplast genome. The Blastn result indicates that the Verbenaceae genus Lantana displays 86% sequence identity with that of Solanaceae genus Nicotiana. Phylogenetic tree was constructed to identify an ideal comparison of L. camara matK gene and other plant species used for the insertion of phbA, phbB, and phbC enzymes, which regulate PHB synthesis. The former can be a good candidate for bioplastic biosynthesis in plant of family Verbanaceae. Our computational results propose that the chloroplast transformation may be useful in biological production of PHB.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs) are a family of biodegradable, renewable plastics that possess properties spanning the range from elastomeric materials to soft films to crystalline materials, allowing their use in a variety of applications currently served by petroleum-based plastics.1 Differences in monomer unit composition, as well as polymer molecular weight, form the basis of the wide range of properties that can be obtained with these plastics.2–5 PHAs exist in nature within various bacteria, where they serve as a carbon storage material when the microbes are faced with a nutrient limitation that impedes their growth, and as a source of energy when more favorable growth conditions return.6,7 PHAs possess excellent stability and shelf life coupled with a unique ability to biodegrade in a wide range of environments, including compost, soil, wetlands, marine and anaerobic digestion facilities.8 The ability to sequester PHAs in bacterial or plant biomass as an inert granular material makes it possible to produce large amounts of a readily convertible polymeric chemical precursor in a biological system where production of the chemical itself might be toxic to the host.

Synthetic polymers can hardly be decomposed in nature.9 Genetic engineering has allowed the enhancement and/or modification of native microbial pathways for PHA production, as well as the transfer of pathways to nonnative producers.10 Significant progress has been made in efforts to produce PHAs in microbial systems using large-scale industrial fermentations of bacteria, and select compositions of materials produced using this technology are in commercial production.10,11 Crop plants can be used as an alternate for large-scale production of PHA, where a plant by-product, such as biomass or seed oil, could be used for the production of energy.

PHB and other related polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHA) are aliphatic polyesters with thermoplastic, insoluble, biodegradable storage polymers,12 produced in many species of bacteria, especially Alcaligenes eutrophus, when grown in medium with an excess of carbon but limited in an essential nutrient, such as nitrogen or phosphorus.13

The most common PHA is poly-β-hydroxybutyrate (PHB), and this polymer can accumulate up to 90% of the cellular dry weight of some bacteria such as Alcaligenes eutrophus.14 The bacterial biosynthetic pathway has a three-step pathway by the successive action of three enzymes viz. β-ketoacyl-CoA thiolase (PhbA), acetoacetyl-CoA reductase (PhbB) and P(3HB) polymerase (PhbC). The three enzymes are encoded by the genes of the phbCAB operon and regulated by identical promoters.15

There are many natural bacteria or even plants that can directly produce PHB. Other PHB biosynthesis genes including phaP, phaR and phaQ have been cloned from Pseudomonas, Alcaligenes, Streptomyces aureofaciens, Azospirillum brasilense, Rhizobium meliloti, Synechocystis spp., Rhodobacter sphaeroides and Rhodospirillum rubrum.16–19 Analyses of the PHB operon in many bacteria show that the phbA and phbB genes are relatively conserved.

In the model plant Arabidopsis (Arabidopsis thaliana), PHB has been produced in leaf tissue samples at levels up to 4% of the tissue’s fresh weight (equivalent to approximately 40% dry weight PHB) in plants engineered with nucleus-encoded expression cassettes for plastid-targeted enzymes. In other plants, PHB levels ranging from trace amounts to 7.7% of the dry weight of the leaf or seed sample have been achieved depending on the plant host. PHB synthesis in biomass crops of industrial interest such as switchgrass (Panicum virgatum), sugarcane (Saccharum spp.) hybrids and corn stover (leaves and stock of Zea mays); have also been reported. Further work, however, is needed to increase levels in these crops for commercial purposes.8

In silico genome cell models are promising tools for accelerating the design of cells with improved and desired properties. Plastids are not transmitted through pollen in most crop species; therefore, the introduction of genes through chloroplast genetic engineering in these plants is a potential route to gene containment.

sec.title: Transplastomic approach in plants
sec.p: One approach to increase product yield is to increase the expression of the PHB pathway genes in the host plant. Plastid-encoded gene expression has yielded extremely high levels of protein production. Maturase K gene (matK) of chloroplast is highly conserved in plant systematics which is involved in Group II intron splicing. This gene has ideal size, high rate of substitution, large proportion of variation at nucleic acid level at first and second codon position, low transition/transversion ratio and the presence of mutationally conserved sectors.

These features of matK gene are exploited in transplastomic production of biodegradable polyester PHB. The matK gene open reading frame (ORF) of L. camara (Gen Bank accession number, AF315303.1) chloroplast chosen is 1331 bp long, located within the intron of the transfer RNA gene, trnL and the adjacent intergenic spacer (IGS) between trnL and trnF. This gene contains high substitution rates within the species and is emerging as potential candidate to study plant systematics and evolution. It is another emerging gene with potential contribution to plant molecular systematics and evolution. The matK–trnK gene complex is commonly used for plant evolution studies and addresses the solution for various taxonomic levels.20

A. thaliana was developed as a model organism for heterologous expression studies subsequently expressing all three phb genes in the plastid. The plastid was targeted for P(3HB) production because of the high level of acetyl-CoA in this organelle, which is the site for lipid biosynthesis. The P(3HB) content in the plastids gradually increased over time, and the maximum amount of P(3HB) in the leaves was 14% of the dry weight. A. thaliana was the first plant of choice for transgenic P(3HB) studies.15

The first attempts to produce PHB in tobacco with plastid-encoded expression of genes encoding the PHB biosynthetic pathway were successful in producing polymer; however, the success was limited in that polymer levels were very low. These experiments were performed with plastid transformation vectors that included minimal, if any, optimization of transgene expression cassettes. Efforts included direct placement of a native bacterial operon behind a plastid promoter, optimization of the ribosome-binding sites of PHB genes in a bacterial operon, placement of a plastid promoter and plastid 5′ untranslated region (UTR) in front of a native bacterial operon, and creation of a genetic construct where expression of the PHB genes is under the control of an ethanol-inducible expression system. Of these strategies, the highest levels of PHB were obtained using a plastidial promoter and 5′ UTR in front of the native bacterial operon.8

Recently, phb genes has also been engineered into cotton (Gossypium hirsutum) and Black Mexican sweet maize (Z. mays), to determine whether P(3HB) formation could alter the characteristics of the cotton fiber.21

sec.title: In silico approach to transplastomic transformation of Lantana camara
sec.p: Lantana camara is a highly invasive nuisance shrub that belongs to the family of Verbanaceae. It is reported to have its origins in the tropics of the Americas but is now found in many African countries including some arid regions. It currently occupies a large percentage of the vegetation cover, wherever it was introduced. Its growth poses a threat to biodiversity.22

Here, we propose using the plastid genome of L. camara to propionic acid metabolism that will lead PHB yields under aerobic conditions. An in silico strategy can predict homology in the plastome trnH–trnK gene of Nicotiana tabacum with trnL–trnF genic sequences of L. camara (Table 1) for the formation of bioplastics. The objective of the present study is to investigate the interfamilial and intrafamilial relationships between plants and bacteria by using dataset which represent all major lineages from families of economic significance.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: Data collection: The entire coding regions of matK sequences of 25 different plant species belonging to 15 families were studied. Generic and species information were obtained from taxonomy database of National Centre for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) (www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/GenBank; Table 1).

Sequence analysis: The data analysis was done for the two grouped datasets. One set includes all the plant species for which the sequences are available in GenBank to find the interspecies variation. Another dataset includes various bacterial genera of, especially, Pseudomonas and Alcaligenes to find intergeneric variation. Multiple sequence alignment was performed by using ClustalW,23 in order to investigate the best fit of sequences in the global database. The gap creation penalty and gap extension penalty were 5 and 1 for the two loci. The genetic distances were seen from the cluster trees which were constructed with neighbor-joining (using bootstrap tests) and maximum-likelihood by the NEIGHBOR program Phylogeny Inference Package (PHYLIP).24 Pairwise global alignment was done using Lalign software.25 The DNA database in FASTA format was analysed by the BLAST program using database of GenBank.

Phylogenetic analysis: The basic sequence statistics including nucleotide frequencies and sequence data was analyzed by neighbor-joining method using NEIGHBOR program Phylogeny Inference Package (PHYLIP).
Analysis of GenBank sequence data: Sequences from the plastid markers trnK/matK, trnL–trnF and rps16 were downloaded from GenBank for in silico comparison.

We compared the sequence similarity of these nucleotide stretches to that of N. tabacum (GenBank accession number Z00044.1), which had successfully undergone plastid transformation. In silico approach is very effective, as it is fast and the reliability of the results is scored based on statistical techniques.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The matK gene sequence of L. camara (GenBank accession number AF315303.1) belonging to the family Verbenaceae, 1331 bp in length, was screened to find homology with matK gene sequences of N. tabacum and A. thaliana, previously documented to have undergone successful plastid transformation (Table 1).

sec.title: Combined analysis
sec.p:
Multiple sequence alignment (Figure 1) shows that there are variable numbers of Indels in the gene matK. The alignment of plant matK gene of combined nucleotide sequence tree show three groups and they are as follows: Group I has three clusters A, B and C. Figure 1.
Phylogram displaying the similarity of Blastn matK gene sequences of plant and bacterial origin after ClustalW analysis.

The cluster A has two clades of families with four species viz. N. tabacum, A. thaliana, Aloe vera and Tradeschantia spathacea showing 86%, 75%, 73% and 70% identity with L. camara (GenBank accession number GQ429057.1) and cluster B has one clade consisting of two species viz. A. thaliana and Raphanas sativus showing 75% identity in each case, whereas cluster C has two clades consisting of three species viz. Azadiracta indica, Gossipium hirsutum and Helianthus annus showing 78%, 80% and 81% identity, respectively. Cluster D has one clade consisting of six species viz. L. camara, Sesamum indicum, N. tabacum, Solanum tuberosum, Atropa beladona and Jatropa showing 100%, 94%, 86% and 85% identity, respectively (Table 1). They are found in tropical regions and are mostly indigenous to India. On Blastn analysis, we found that in clade group A, families Solanaceae, Brassicaceae, Xanthorrhoeaceae and Commelinaceae had high similarities; whereas, group D members had families with high-percentage identities viz. Verbenaceae, Pedaliaceae, Solanaceae and Euphorbiaceae (Figure 1). In group D, plant species belonging to Solanaceae had highly similar sequences and less variants, namely, N. tabacum (GenBank accession number HQ619839.1), S. Tuberosum (GenBank accession number HQ619841.1 and Z11741.1), Atropa belladonna (GenBank accession number AJ585882.1) and Jatropa gossipiifolia (GenBank accession number GU441803.1).

However, sequence statistics and Blastn results showed sequences of L. camara trnL–trnF gene (GenBank accession number HM216633.1) and rps16 (GenBank accession number EU348856.1) yielded uncertain homology to that of N. tabacum trnH–trnK (GenBank accession number HQ602917.1) and A. thaliana trnL–trnF gene (GenBank accession number AY122452.1).

The GC content and CpG islands scattered in the genome might influence the integration of bacterial phb genes in the phyto-matK gene.7 The GC content of N. tabaccum partial chloroplast genome and matK gene were found to be 38 and 33.69, respectively; number of CpG islands being 41 and 22, respectively. On the other hand, when L. camara chloroplast matK gene was screened using BitGene software, the GC and CpG content was found to be 35.3 and 28, respectively (Figure 2). Figure 2.
Graphical representation of GC content and number of CpG islands in various plants with similar identities and less variants after BitGene analysis.

These values are of significance as the GC content of the DNA sequence plays vital role effecting integration capacities of foreign DNA segments. Putting aside the obvious differences in morphology of tobacco and L. camara plants, it is interesting to see that more than 86% of the L. camara and tobacco chloroplast matK genes have regions of DNA homology as confirmed by their Blastn output (Table 1).

PHB sequence analysis: Nucleotide sequence analysis using Lalign software25 revealed that the bacterial genes encoding phbA, phbB and phbC in A. eutrophus showed significant sequence similarity to matK gene of L. camara, calculating the global alignment of the two sequences displayed percentage identity between A. eutrophus phb A and phbB (J04987.1) versus N. tabacum chloroplast partial genome (GenBank accession number Z00044.1) to be 37.7%, and with A. eutrophus phbC gene (GenBank accession number M64341.1) to be 40%. On the other hand, the L. camara matK gene (GenBank accession number AF315303.1) showed a percentage identity of 32.4% and 40.2% with A. eutrophus phbA/B and phbC gene, respectively (Figure 3). Figure 3.
Lalign output showing sequence identity of matK gene sequence of plastid-transformed plants with bacterial Alcaligenes eutrophus sequence phbA/B/C gene.

In silico plastid transformation in L. camara: In chloroplast transformation experiments with tobacco, numerous regions of the chloroplast genome were suitable target sites for the uptake of transgenes.26 In the course of this work, we identified a region in the chloroplast genome of L. camara that, when used in transformation exercises for homologous recombination, could result in particularly high chloroplast transformation frequencies.
It has been reported that PHB genes have high sequence difference in different strains.27 However, the three genes are related to PHB biosynthesis by bioinformatics prediction.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our work has helped in identifying the probable recombination regions of phb enzymes in L. camara and in reconstructing the possible pathways using in silico techniques. These identifications can be used for further analysis of the phb pathways.

As we have seen from earlier studies, the results obtained from computational techniques are highly reliable and have been experimentally validated. But, our results had a few discrepancies. The most important was that the matK genes of L. camara showed relatively less homology with that of other PHB-producing plants, that is, 72% with A. thaliana, 80% with G. hirsutum and 85% with S. tuberosum (Lalign). On the whole, this study has provided insight in chloroplast genetic engineering phb-producing pathways involved in eukaryotic systems, and will aid in understanding similar pathways in other plant systems.

The first step toward the production of these novel biopolymers in plants is through genetic engineering was A. thaliana. Production of a large quantity of PHB or PHA in plants will require additional genetic manipulations to divert reduced carbon away from endogenous metabolic pathways and to regulate the tissue specificity, timing of expression and cellular localization of the enzymes involved. It might be possible to divert carbon from synthesis of storage lipids toward PHB production in plastids, where accumulation of PHB granules may not have deleterious effects.

This approach offers a number of attractive advantages, including high-level transgene expression, multigene engineering in a single transformation event, transgene containment via maternal inheritance, lack of gene silencing, position effect due to site-specific transgene integration and lack of pleiotropic effects due to subcellular compartmentalization of transgene products.28 Additionally, plastid transformation of recalcitrant crops such as cotton and soybean allows the application of the cytoplasmic male-sterile system to commercially important crops.29

Deleterious effects of constitutive transgene expression can occur if gene products are harmful to the transformed plant. Constraints such as growth inhibition and male sterility have been observed in plastid transformants containing the phb operon encoding the genes required for the production of the polyester PHB.30

Success has been achieved in metabolic engineering of the tobacco plant by introducing multiple genes within a bacteria-like operon into a plastid genome.31 A tobacco plastid was transformed with a polycistron consisting of the spectinomycin resistance gene and three bacterial genes for the biosynthesis of the biodegradable polyester, PHB.31

Since, in contrast to bacteria, eukaryotic cells are highly compartmentalized, there are a number of challenges in expressing phb genes in plants. The phb genes must be targeted to the compartment of the plant cells where the concentration of acetyl-CoA is the highest, but only in such a way that growth of the plant is not restricted.6,8

The present report of synthesis of PHB in L. camara represents a first step toward the production of the biopolymer in a plant considered a weed and growing luxuriantly via genetic engineering. Production of a large quantity of PHB or PHA L. camara will require additional genetic manipulations to divert reduced carbon away from endogenous metabolic pathways and to regulate the tissue specificity, timing of expression and cellular localization of the enzymes involved. It might be possible to divert carbon from synthesis of storage lipids toward PHB production in plastids, where accumulation of PHB granules may not have deleterious effects.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Computational simulation indicated a region of chloroplast genome of L. camara which may be used in chloroplast transformation. The computational results indicate that L. camara can be useful in biological production of PHB at a reduced cost. Although our work has shown that chloroplast transformation has the potential for massive production of PHB in a stable and environmentally sound manner, there are still a lot of problems to be resolved before this technology can be really applied for commercial production. For example, the plant species suitable for plastome technology need to be expanded so that a wide range of plants can become candidates for chloroplast-mediated PHB production; the rate of inserting gene into the chloroplast genome needs to be increased to the level viable for bulk production, obviously, the limits of transgenic PHA production are unpredictable.

Current industrial production systems extensively utilize metabolically engineered bacteria to produce specialized polymers with specific, desirable properties. This attests to the value of PHBs as commercially viable products and to the utility of metabolic engineering strategies for their production. We can expect that many more phytoplastic factories will be constructed in the near future making PHB availability cheap, abundant and biodegradable.

notes.title: Biographies
notes.p: Dr Protiti Bose persuaded her doctorate in microbiology and thereafter has been engaged in research and teaching. She is presently working as a scientist in molecular biology with specialization in human genomics. She has several publications and is a member of International Science Congress Association.

Dr Rahul Shrivastava persuaded his MSc, PhD in Biochemistry and is currently working as an associate professor in Department of Bioinformatics, Maulana Azad National Institute of Technology, Bhopal (MP), India, and he is engaged in proteomics and metabolomics research. He has several national and international publications in reputed journals and he is a member of various academic societies.
